column1: #Text=`reachml` is a library for recourse verification.
#Text=*Recourse* is the ability of a decision subject to change the prediction of a machine learning model through actions on their features.
#Text=*Recourse verification* aims to tell if a decision subject is assigned a prediction that is fixed.
#Text=You can install the library as follows:
#Text=Many of the functions in `reach-ml` will require [CPLEX](https://www.ibm.com/products/ilog-cplex-optimization-studio) to run properly.
#Text=The command above will install CPLEX Community Edition.
#Text=The community edition has a strict limit on the number of constraints it can support.

#Text=To avoid these, you will want install reachml without the cplex option, and download and install the full version of IBM CPLEX [following these instructions](https://github.com/ustunb/risk-slim/blob/master/docs/cplex_instructions.md).
#Text=The following example shows how to specify actionability constraints using `ActionSet` and to build a database of `ReachableSet` for each point.
#Text=# `ActionSet` infers the type and bounds on each feature from `X`.
#Text=## print(action_set) should return the following output
#Text=##|   | name                     |  type  | actionable | lb | ub | step_direction | step_ub | step_lb |
#Text=action_set[["age", "marital_status"]].actionable = False # these features cannot or should not change
#Text=action_set["years_since_last_default"].ub = 100 # set maximum value of feature to 100
#Text=action_set["years_since_last_default"].step_ub = 1 # limit actions to changes value by 1
#Text=# Specify constraint to maintain one hot-encoding on `job_type`
#Text=# if `years_since_last_default` increases, then `age` must increase commensurately
#Text=# This will force `age` to change even though it is not immediately actionable
#Text=# Check that `ActionSet` is consistent with observed data
#Text=# For example, if features must obey one-hot encoding, this should be the case for X
#Text=# Build a database of reachable sets for all points
#Text=# Pull reachable set for first point in dataset
#Text=##    age  marital_status  years_since_last_default  job_type_a  job_type_b  job_type_c
#Text=Given a classifier `clf` with a predict method, you can test if a point has recourse as `np.any(clf.predict(reachable_set.X))`
#Text=script](https://github.com/ustunb/reachml/blob/main/research/iclr2024/scripts/setup_dataset_actionset_fico.py) which sets up the action set for the FICO dataset.
#Text=For more about recourse verification, check out our paper ICLR 2024 spotlight paper: [Prediction without Preclusion](https://openreview.net/forum?
#Text=If you use this library in your research, we would appreciate a citation:
#Text=    title={Prediction without Preclusion: Recourse Verification with Reachable Sets},
#Text=    author={Avni Kothari and Bogdan Kulynych and Tsui-Wei Weng and Berk Ustun},
#Text=    booktitle={The Twelfth International Conference on Learning Representations},
#Text=The code for the paper is available under [research/iclr2024](https://github.com/ustunb/reachml/tree/main/research/iclr2024/).
